reviews.review_text: Ronin is a very fun game but many people may have huge faults with the game.   First of all there is really no story at all in the game, there is small bits but overall there is nothing to call a story. So instead of gunpoint where you know why you are going in and doing the this job, you just kill random people to get data to kill a boss character. Sadly we don't even know anything about our character...you can assume who she is in the picture but that is it. On a side note i want to know about the 2 guys other then the assume dad and the normal ninja guy in the picture, i want to know why we don't kill them.  Gameplay it is very fun and enjoyable. Yes there is many bugs where you teleport around but it happened when i screwed up already, but i see how it could be a huge problem. Luckly there is checkpoints every 3 minutes so really the glitches are small 'aww i got to kill these 2 people again' then doing a whole level again. I feel sad that the game is only 4 ish hours long, well 8 counting NG+ but overall a very short game.  Music i really did enjoy and liked listening to, it fit the action of the scene and always nice to have some heartpumping action music while you slow down time and kill 5 people in a room. You can see this as a bad thing but to me the music was one of the best parts of the game in my mind.  The last thing is NG+. Now i did find it interesting that they change one enemy's attack which made the game harder and the obvious more guys in a room. Weirdly i found the game easier in NG+....with all the abilities i had and how easier to get the abilities i just found it easier. The only time i had huge troubles was the final guy where i had to do a certain pattern to beat him, but overall i wished there was more put into NG+.  Basically i had fun and found it enjoyable. I feel like gunpoint is better then this, but i had more heartpumping moments in this. If i have to give this a rating, i give it a 7.5, there is huge problems with glitchs and the fact no story makes you sometimes go 'why am i even killing this guy?'. Not the best game in the genre but a fun game to play

Purchased via a humble bundle, so no refund in my future. But this game had a great idea - turn based action, dodging according to sight lines, planning out encounters - and really sank it all by being very fiddly and unpredictable. This game really should have had more playtesting and care put into designing areas, encounters and the basic platforming. What became the breaking point between 'this is kind of aggravating' and 'this game deserves a bad review' is the in-level tip, that 'The jump arc is a lie.'  That really brings home all the problems. When it's about precise attack dodging and knocking down enemies, doing little frog hops instead of leaping into someone aiming a gun at you means resetting. Trying to jump onto someone near a ledge sometimes means knocking in just underneath it, and there's no helping you if all you need to do is go up instead of jumping around aimlessly to do a simple climb. The jump arc is essential to playing the game, but is unreliable and frustrating; that's not funny, that's just poor design.

Ronin is a game that seems to have aped half the code from Gunpoint and added a single original gimmick. The gimmick is this turn-based combat system that has you jumping around from place to place, trying to avoid gunfire so that you can get up close to stab your enemies with a sword. When it works, it's pretty brilliant. It's a good mechanic, but it lacks polish, and when your one original idea comes with serious bugs, it ruins the entire game. The big issue is that this jumping ballet requires extreme precision, and very tactical thought, as a single mistake will see you dead, and so when the game tells you your jump is going to land you in a certain area, you need to be able to trust with 100% certainty that you will land where expected, else you are likely to die. The problem is that a decent percentage of the time, the game will screw up your trajectory just enough to get you killed, and see you frustratingly replay the same section over and over and over again.  Worse is when the game decides abruptly, and for very little reason, to suddenly drop you out of the turn-based play, and back into real time. If an enemy spots you but you're too far away to attack, they will call in a Lockdown, which can screw up your progress, or cause automatic failure of the level. It takes them 9 turns, or 9 seconds, to initiate the lockdown, giving you 9 turns, or 9 seconds, to reach them and stop them from putting through the call. 9 turns is difficult enough in some of the particularly dangerous levels, where there are a dozen enemies around you, all trying to shoot you dead every turn. When the game suddenly drops you into real-time mode, you can suddenly lose 2-3 seconds before you even realize what's happened, and now you've gone from 8 turns to 5 turns through no fault of your own.  The game can easily be beaten in less than 4 hours, if you're decent at it and the game doesn't screw up repeatedly and cause you to have to replay sections of the game again and again and again. Two sections in particular, which should have been 5 minute sections to beat, took me over 90 minutes to beat because I kept dying. Sometimes it was my own fault, the game can be a challenge even when it's working flawlessly, which is a good thing, but a good chunk of the time I died because the game didn't do what it said it'd do, and got me killed as a result.  Bottom line: The game is reasonably fun, but I'd wait for it to go on a massive sale. Even at the entirely reasonable $10-13 dollar range it just doesn't feel like enough game, and the bugginess can really hurt the fun. If you can get it for $5, and don't mind some frustration, there's a fairly decent game here.

I enjoyed almost all of Ronin, the mechanics are interesting (if a little unpredictable at times) and completing the levels while still trying to get all the objectives makes for some enjoyable puzzle-y stabby action. Plotting your route through the levels and trying to pick off as many enemies as possible before the inevitable fire fight is fun enough to make this a certain positive recommendation.  BUT. The decision to design the last level without a single checkpoint is so staggeringly idiotic that it makes me want to scream. All enjoyment is sucked out of trying to solve the puzzles it presents because any attempt at experimentation is punished with having to play the first half of the level all over again. And now, right at the end of the game that element of unpredictability (will that jump work as the trajectory suggests? Will I clip an enemy on the way past? Will that guard hit me or will I fly through the gap unscathed?) crashes into your living room and punches you repeatedly in the balls. The first half of the level is not so good that I want to replay it a billion times just to get to the later sections.  I appreciate that this is ameliorated slightly by a new mechanic and it (sort of) plays into the storyline but I fail to see how that is an improvement over having a sensible checkpoint system which would let the player choose how they want to approach it.  Do not buy this, do not support this kind of design decision.

RONIN is an incredibly good indie game, with a lot of clear thought and effort put into it. It has an emotional twist at the end which I will not spoil. The gameplay is addicting and tactical, while also being simple to pick up but hard to master. Over-all, I think this game deserves my solid reccomendation to any and all of my friends.

As you can see from my playtime I loved this game. Yet it's far from flawless; a lot of wall-collision bugs, a few game design mistakes make it next to impossible to clear with a controller on NG+, (mouse and keyboard mandatory on NG+). The game is also a bit too short and there's a good replay value only for 'meta'-completionists, ie : being able to set goals and challenges for yourself. (for instance I've been making time attack runs with or w/o wall-bug)  If these few flaws don't bother you or if you find it in a bundle then by all means buy it ! It has a lot of interesting and original gameplay mechanics, its hybrid turnbased/realtime gameplay makes it something unique and very fun to experiment with.  Also very nice music by Patryk Karwat.  All in all a very unique and memorable game.

Amazingly fun 2D turn-based sneaking game. You can play it by ether going allmost full stealth and strategizing your way through or just slash every enemy without caring about the alarm, either way its fun to play once you get hang of the controls. I recommend everyone who like stealth games tries it out!

Turn Based Ninja Combat with some Stealth on top, if that somehow sounds exciting to you then you will probably enjoy this game. I readed a lot of bad reviews due to either framerate or keyboard controls or even the skill progresion system... and they are all right, but I dont care because the combat is SO much fun.  If you like dinamic puzzle games (Tactical games, Stealth games and so on) you´ll probably like this, and if you ever fantasized about being an unstopable ninja in an action scene, then you might love this.
Wrote a review of this for IGN Norway. Gave it 9.5 out of 10
I adore this game, the learning curve is steap and unforgiving yet it is very rewarding, well done devs!

Don't let the turn based system turn you away in case you're into into that kind of action. This is a VERY fast-paced game, in which thinking one step ahead is the key to success, all while slashing your enemies and dodging telegraphed bullets at the same time. The checkpoint system is VERY generous, so there aren't any extreme aspects to this game other than some difficult encounters here and there.  One of the most favorite things I liked was that you get to freely decide how to deal with enemies and not being restricted to follow a script, allowing a very dynamic gameplay. As you keep playing you'll earn more skills to spice up the game, and for the challengers among you - there is NG+ which provides even more intense setting.  You can probably count the turn based games I ever played on one hand, and I can only wish future turn based games will give me as much satisfaction as this did.
This game is rad.

RONIN is good for its price, especially since there are almost no other games like it available. It's between Mark of the Ninja and Gunpoint, taking a bit from both but never feeling too derivative.  The good: * When fights work out, they feel extremely satisfying. * You can feel like a bullet-dodging ninja :D * The game isn't overloaded with unnecessary UI clutter and rules. * Quite a few segments can be done predator style, if you want to.  The bad:  * Sometimes you glitch through a wall, end up locked in and have to restart from checkpoint. * The lockdown mechanic feels a bit forced. * Due to the fact that movement isn't precise, many encounters will result in trial and error. * Levels are somewhat linear.

Decent level design with unique, interactive gameplay, making this a fantastic first game for this developer. Although the gameplay is fantastic, there is very little plot and only 5 or so hours of Ninja Action, making it a little short for the price.   Overall, buy it if you like fantastic immersive platforming but not for the plot.

I bought this game expecting absolutely nothing. After three hours of constant dieing and frustration, it struck me. THIS IS GUNPOINT KILL BILL! Since kill bill is one of my favorite movies of ALL TIME I really started enjoying RONIN. The artwork and music perfectly suited the game and I really got into the groove at Club Wisegal. The game was short and mechanics were a little glitchy but if you grab it on sale it's worth it.
Fun but short. Very dificult in some points but never frustrating. New game + adds in some real ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t though.

I've tried to like this game, I really did. Its a 2d turn based action platformer. It sounds like a unique mix of genres and just strange enough to pique my interest. Artistically it looks like Gunpoint, which I loved, but that is about the extent of the similarities between the two.  My biggest gripe with the game has to do with the controls. A game like this needs tight controls and I feel like this game does not have it. There have been plenty of occasions when trying to jump in combat the trajectory says I will clear certain obstactles but when I carry out said action my character only slides forward and inch or so leading to my death. Also other times it seems that on a second attemot I will perform the same set of actions but the npcs will act entirely differently.  There are other concerns about the game but I don't want to go into some long rant about all of the problems I see. Rather I would just like to highlight the most glaring issues that made the experience more frustrating than enjoyable for me.

Short, but satisfying. I loved playing through it, and has a nice challenge to it. it has a lot of replay value, I replayed it 3 times.
The gameplay is simple, but phenomenal! Highly recommended!

At the time of writing this review, I had about twenty minutes dedicated to this game. The number one thing I have to say about this game is; It is not that bad. Seriously it's not. But the reason I do not recommend Ronin is because it feels like a flash game. No kidding. The mechanics are awesome, but the story and one note levels are those that you'd expect from something off of Kongregate. Like I said before, the game is not horrible. It could use a lot of work though. A whole lot.

Played 45 minutes of this game and i think this game is a disappointment to me, really. It's difficult and unforgiving unlike Gunpoint. Gunpoint can be difficult at times, but RONIN? 3 minutes in and i died, and i died, and i died, and so on. Seriously, if you're looking for this kind of game, grab Gunpoint, not this :( 5/10

It's a very cool update on Gunpoint's mechanics.  *IT IS NOT AN ACTION OR STEALTH GAME* (there is a little of each)  It's a tactical game. You have free movement till combat initiates, at which point everything is turn based. So you've got plenty of time to decide where to jump, what to kill, who to knock through which window... It's a lot of fun.  Unfortunately, it's eventually let down by the imprecise controls, which are not nearly tight or capable enough to handle things from the fourth level boss on. It's at that point that you'll die, and die a lot, and worse, only part of the time will it feel like your fault. But even with that still very worth playing.
Great, though short, game. Got frustrating a few times, but that makes it all the more satisfying to have beaten.
Pros: I feel like the most badassiest badass in the history of badass  Cons: mother♥♥♥♥ing civilians

Ronin is a turn based 'stealth' action game which draws inspiration from the highly acclaimed Mark of the Ninja and Gunpoint. Being a huge fan of Klei's Mark of the Ninja this game didn't live up to the expectations as its execution is simply flawed in the key areas of combat and level design.   Pros

RONIN, a game that looks like a stealth game but is actually just a trigger-happy trap.   Can I kill this enemy sillently while being in the dark ?  No, because the other guy will look that way exactly at that moment.  The turned-based idea is great, the animation is good, the artistic design is deluxe but that is not enough to keep me from hating the triggers in the game.

The artstyle looks like the games developed by Klei which is a really nice thing. The music is used sparsely but fits the dystopian thriller-feeling but the story is non-existant. Anything else would be a lie. Another lie (contributed by Steam reviewers) that this game is a stealth game which it is definetly not. You have almost no option to sneak, so Ronin is an action-platformer with turn based combat. The gameplay works but in my opinion the game design has some flaws. For example the skills you unlock. You can only use them, when you use a form of combo which is stupid in my opinion. Also the AI is too picky for me. But all of this would be ok if this had not been so repetetive. You arrive at a level. You need to hack computers, engage in some combat, hack another computer, engage in combat again. Then you leave and have to get to your motorbike WHICH IS IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION OF ARRIVAL. The game is a 7/10. Can't really recommend it, there are better games to play in my opinion. The game is not bad though, by any means.

It's a really, really cool game. If you're good enough, you actually feel like some sort of ninja, popping inside a building and leaping around massacring everyone.  HOWEVER, the experience is hindered by the clunky control and the unreliable mechanic. Even after more than an hour of playing I still having difficulty controlling my jump. And unreliablity: sometimes when the samurai enemy lands nearby, I got slain right away, while another time I randomly not get slain. This kind of chaotic mechanic is good for a real-time gameplay, but is a big no-no for a turn-based gameplay since you want to plan your moves ahead.  Also, I finished the first 5 levels in an hour, and there are only 15 levels? =/

Fun, and fairly short to really beat thoroughly(4 hrs for all optional objective playthrough, 9 for that + new game plus playthrough). I have to give it negative marks for the last level, which completely changes how the game works. Goes from checkpoints allowing you to slowly but surely progress through the level, into having to do the entire level in one go. I only encountered one, but there are also some physics bugs where I jumped into a fake 'room' that couldn't be escaped. I'll change my review to positive if the developer ever fixes the last level.

I really wanted to enjoy Ronin but it's controls butcher the experience. Often times I would point my mouse towards a different portion of the screen to move the character only to have him drop down and get killed. It becomes trial and error and it doesn't make for a fun gameplay experience. Whats also strange is not being able to use arrow keys to do simple things like get in an elevator. It's awkward as all hell.
This is a fun game and really enjoyable, The but is it is sooo short and there seems to be more people on the photo and it just seems to stop
Too addicting guys. I havnt played a game that got me worked up as much as this game does in a long time. Brilliant, and loads of fun
Not a bad game at all! Fun even when its very punishing to you.

A rather unique game along the lines of Gunpoint, its incredibly atmospheric and has a really stand out soundtrack. I feel like some of the mechanics could have been polished slightly, but I thoroughly enjoyed the gameplay despite that minor gripe.
Just straight up broken. Mouse-based controls don't come close to being functional when running at 3440 x 1440.

I really enjoyed this game. The strategy involved reminded me of chess, as in when you are being targetted it's like you're in check & if you don't make the right move to get out of situation, you lose. The abilities your character has & can obtain were fun to combined. The controls were tricky to get the hang of & were only an issue when I tried to get my character to do one thing and she did something else. The only things that 'really' bothered me was that the character couldn't roll (or someother direct side movement) during combat, and the level progression style changed on the final level (however I can understand why the change would make sense & be fun for other players). The story could have done with a little more depth (or rather I would have liked to know more). Overall I really enjoyed it & would love to see either a sequel or anther in the same style.
This game makes for very cool fights that seem to happen on bullet time. Great fight puzzles, and tough enough to not get boring.

Pros - cool style, soundtrack is nice. Cons - level design is too simple, game is way too short, detection system is just facepalm, turn-based mechanic may seem cool but I find it weird and not fun to play, replay value is close to zero.

Madly challenging game that deserves so much more publicity than it already has.  Pros- +Challenging gameplay +Rewards careful planning +You're a ninja chick. That's pretty cool +You get to slice up dudes with your sick af katana +Beast soundtrack +Sweet art style that reminds me of Samurai Jack  Cons- -Those f*cking landmines -Seriously f*ck those things -Jump arc is occasionally innacurate. Frustrating in high risk combat situations -Landmines again. I mean really, f*ck those godamn landmines  Despite the landmines, this game is pretty damn good. Reccomended for those who want to be shot in the stomach around 50 times at a disco called 'Swordpoint'  (EDIT) Also, f*ck the 'Kill the Officer' level. That's just ridiculous. I mean seriously. That's bloody ridiculous. It's damn near impossible to do without raising the alarm. There are guys bloody everywhere  (EDIT AGAIN) I did it

I bought this game for only six dollars during the stealth game sale... Even at the lowered price I found this game to be a waste of my time and money. The turn base system is weird and frusturating things like the inacuracy of the jump lines and not being able to walk in combat made it clunky and annoying. The game is riddled with glitches and bugs multiple times I would phase through a wall or fly out of the world. The art style and music was nice but I couldn't appreciate it's full potential because of the alarming problems.   When I bought the game I thought it would be a Gunpoint or Mark of The Ninja with a twist. I was left with a game where the main challenge was trying not to fall through the floor.  5/10
There is a reason this ronin's master disowned him.
Beautiful concept, but the game is ridden with bugs and terrible gameplay as of this writing. Don't waste your money on this untested game.

Its a great concept but the developer should have taken more time to refine the control and tweak things such as enemies attacking out of turn. Suddenly freezing during your turn sequence and not being able to do anything but get killed.  It has a good check point system that makes it a bit less frustrating than Hotline Miami. But its also very linear, at a glance the large levels may appear that you have a choice in direction and plotting your assault. However you really don't, as you'll notice by you guide points of entry. I bought this on sale so its not a huge loss, but its a $10 game that still needs work to be complete. Also you can't turn off the 'Tips' without editing the game files. 'The Jump Arc is a Lie' is probably the most accurate one.
The checkpoints are not consistent and controls are crap. It's not worth the price.

First off, I got this from the recent Devolver Humble Bundle and I'm thoroughly enjoying it. I've seen some gripes that this shouldn't be considered a stealth game and I agree... if you either play the game fast and loose or are just bad at staying out of sight. It IS a stealth game if you stay out of sight lines (literal, red sight lines) and know what order to take targets out in. Regardless of what genre it's considered, I've greatly enjoyed it. It does get a bit frustrating when, for instance, someone starts calling in a lockdown that shouldn't have been able to see/hear you or when you go to jump down to a lower platform/floor and you just jump a molecule forward (usually getting killed because of this). The menu also seems to 'lag' a bit at times. Other than that, it's a great game. However, I wouldn't pay $12.99 for this. $4.99 - $9.99 would have been a better price range, so you might want to wait for a sale. $12.99 isn't, by an means, highway robbery, but it feels a bit salty to me (and why I waited for a bundle/sale).  Score: 7.5/10  EDIT: Welp, had an in-game hint tell me this isn't a stealth game, just kill everyone lol... I disagree, though.

this game have a great idea. but not executed in a good way. its really annoying. here is an example  1. the game switch between free run mode and turn base mode at stupid times that get you killed after doing alot of effort and alot of time on a hard level. then you lose ? why ? a guard saw you and the 8 seconds timer started and you had no freaking idea.  2. swinging in this game is more then horrible. you spend milions of trys just to swing through a wide window.  3.no story what so ever.  4.how is this taged as a Stealth game i will never know.  buy it only if you like getting annoyed and if its on at least 50% sale..

This is one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played.  The controls could be better, and it isn't as easy to predict outcomes as you'd like sometimes, but instead of crying about it you need to ninja up and admit it was your own lack of foresight and planning that got you killed. again. and again, and again.   I hope they make a sequel, with that last piece of polish on the controls and with an even ballerer final level.
Play Gunpoint instead. Very similar mechanics, way better execution.

You don't make a game where one hit kills you if your controls aren't alright. It ask you to be precise, but the dev haven't been precise in doing the controls. Could be a very cool game for the rest, if it wasn't so frustrating.

The control scheme for mouse and keyboard is ridiculous. Although NOTHING in the game tells you this, attacking an enemy requires you to click the air above their head, and opening a door requires you to click the ground a few feet underneath it. Easily the single most unintuitive and ill-conceived scheme I have ever seen. The xbox controls are no better - the right stick will always waver on returning to the center, altering the direction of the jump a fraction of a second before it lauches. Incredibly frustrating.

RONIN is Truly one of the most dissapointing games ive ever bought. this game has extremely promising combat system thats let down by a number of different things. first off. when you get into combat, you lose alot of control over your charater. you cant move, roll, or anything besides jumping and using your sword. there maybe more options from the unlock system but i havent bothered playing after the first few levels. the jumping is just to weak to be satisfying. it also dosent help that you are often stuck in small rooms with dozens of enemies. more than half of the time, you'll die and there is nothing you can do about it, all because of the lack of movement. but i could look past most of the previously stated problems if it wasnt for the awfull unlock system. to unlock a skill point. you need to finish all of the 'Optional' objectives. these optional objectives remain the same all thorough the game ( atleast the part i played anyway ). the objectives are simple, dont kill civies, dont trigger the alarm, and kill every single enemy. more than half of the time. the alarm is going to be the only thing that keeps you from getting a skill point. enemies with always start the alarm when they lose sight of you. but even then, if they hear glass shatter, or a gunshot, they start the alarm. this means that they could be on another, inaccesable, part of the level. the one thing letting this entire thing down is the skill point system. i could forgive the controls. and the cramped rooms. if this feature was tweaked. save yourself from the fustration and dont buy this title, if you are looking for a similar type of game. go buy Gunpoint. that game will give you far more enjoyment than this game.

While the idea behind the combat is interesting and the art and music are nice, I sadly can't recommend this game because of how inconsistent the movement is. In a game where one shot kills you and you have to plan very carefully because of that, the game needs to tell you exactly what locations are safe for the next turn, which kills are safe for the next turn, etc. I died so many times because I thought I could take that kill, but then one shot just touched my helmet, because of the position my body ended the turn in, or the other way around, where I was sure that shot would kill me, but then it went through my leg and nothing happened. That inconsistency just made the game too frustrating to play, which is sad, because when you actually manage to massacre an entire room full of gun-wielding agents and sci-fi-samurai with nothing but a sword (and some special abilites) you do feel pretty bad-♥♥♥.

The fundamental premise and game mechanics of RONIN are really good fun but it's let down by simply being too difficult. You need to play the same sections over and over and over to make progress and despite the game being fun, it's not fun enough to prevent it getting laborious.  It also suffers a bit from being obtuse, the tutorial and hints simply aren't good enough and so it'll take you a while to figure out some pretty basic stuff. If that wasn't enough, it also does that thing a lot of games do where it unlocks skills that make the game easier if you fulfill some pretty tricky criteria, essentially making the game easier for people who already find it easier and more difficult for people who are finding it difficult.
The control scheme is terrible. You jump by pointing the right joystick and there's no way to cancel a jump. On top of that, the jump arc indicator is just wrong most of the time.
dosn't work iv'e got all recomodations!!! Sh!t Game
DO NOT GET this game has SOOOOOOOOOO many bugs and the level design is terible tbh the demo is more enjoyable than this game

Bought the Humble Devolver bundle specifically for this game. A quick look at some videos had me expecting a cross between Mark of the Ninja and Gunpoint. Shortly into the game the on screen hints almost directly told me I was not getting that, with one hint saying 'This is not Gunpoint' and another saying 'This isn't a stealth game, just kill everything.' They're not lying. You are easily spotted and there's really no way, or reason, to avoid it most of the time. I played through the first 5 or 6 missions before getting frustrated and bored. I put it down and tried Not a Hero, another game from the same bundle that I had no interest in. I played that one through to completion and still play it just for fun.   For the record, my play time is low because Steam doesn't track offline play time. I had to run the game online for a few minutes just to be able to write this review.

It has the most clunky, poorly explained controls of any game I've ever played.  Let me say this. Neo Aquarium. A game that's known for it's ♥♥♥♥ poor controls, plays better than this does.  Which is a shame, since everything else about it's simplistic design is charming.
Very short, but well worth it! Music on the nightclub level made me stay a bit longer.

I loved this game for the following reasons.  1. Its turn based 2. Awesome concept 3. Its challenging without being utterly frustrating  Things I won't hold against it  1. Its kind of like a platformer - but not  Ultimately I really enjoyed this game. There was no point in the game where I could say that it was broken or that I had broken it. All the skills choices in the world don't really make up for good panning and execution. Although there can be so many variables in a level that unless you look around first and decide which path you will take to accomplish your goal it can become rather full on.  10/10

Ronin is Gunpoint without the humor and with wonky controls. A lot of the challenges seem to rely less on a sound plan, than on pure luck. That being said... It's still a fun game, but very frustrating. I'd buy gun Gunpoint first and if that doesn't scratch the itch, then wait for Ronin to go on sale.
Stylish platformer with fun mechanics
A ninja murder simulator with complex jumps.  I really quite like it. It's challenging.

This is not a stealth game. This is not a gunpoint clone.  Once you get rid of those two thoughts and get your head around the reactive/tactical combat system the game really flows smoothly. After you unlock some skills and get some practice with aiming the jumps and grapple swings you will float through rooms of enemies like a Pinball of death.  It's a bit short,It took just about 5 hours for me to get through the game with completing all the optional goals on all the levels.There is a new game+ that let's you play through again with slightly harder enemies while keeping all your unlocked abilities.   As of writing this on 9/19/15 there is an occasional bug which lead to you or an enemy getting knock though a wall but it doesn't happen often and the checkpoint system means it's not even close to being a game breaker.  Another negative is that the story is almost non existent.  All in all I'd say it's just about worth buying at full price for the experience. If you ever get the chance to buy it for under $9 I'd say it's well worth it.

A pretty solid stealth game somewhere inbetween Mark of the Ninja and Gunpoint with a good ambient/chill-out soundtrack. Turn-based combat and time freezing mechanics add an interesting twist to the genre. There are a few flaws though: - controller support is pretty poor - I had to highly increase right stick sensitivity just to have my actions detected - having to restart from the beginning when you exit a level it's quite punishing given the length of levels and the amount of randomness/luck implied in each combat - some bugs let you unintentionally teleport through glass windows (which is cool) and slide through platforms (which is often not)  Overall I would recommend this game, hoping that programmer will add patches in the future.

Ronin is heaviliy influenced by the style and gameplay of Gunpoint (to the point I actually had to look up if it was the same person behind it). But superficial similarities aside, it's a very different game, as the tutorials keep reminding you ('This is not a stealth game! Kill everyone!) Where Gunpoint was a stealth game in realtime, Ronin is a turn-based action game with some stealth elements, and in that respect it has more similarities to Superhot or even chess than Gunpoint. All that insane fight choreography you see in movies and other games, it has to be meticulously planned in this game. That's not to be miscontrued as something boring: there's a certain thrill in having to plan ahead for where your position will need to be a few rounds ahead for that fatal blow to land, knowing full well that you may need to adapt your plans and moves depending on what the enemy AI chooses to do. It's a great little game to pass the time, though it can feel really hard at times, unfortunately more because of the controls glitching rather than skill, when for example a leap's projected arc end up in an akward mini leap that's barely a step in legth and will result in a bullet to the face. Thankfully the game is forgiving with its checkpoints.

Ronin's concept seems interesting, but the gameplay is so janky I'm not sure it would even be fun on a mobile device. I say this because the interface looks like it might be for mobile. I just can't enjoy anything about the way Ronin feels to play. There's too much pausing in all the wrong places and the overly simple control layout has resulted in excessive deaths rather than exact control. The design is just so clunky and inexplicable to me I can't even explain fully why I hate it. Not recommended.
